msItem.filiation: This homily draws on the poem Judgement Day II, which in turn depends on De die iudicii.

physDesc.p: There are also a number of emendations by the Tremulous Hand of Worcester.

handNote.p: Ker's scribe 'O'. The scribe Wulfgeat. A round Anglo-Saxon miniscule. A slight lean to the right. Round, unroofed a; a mixture of descending insular long s and tall s; round d with short ascender that usually has a small flick or curve to the upper-right at its tip. Ash is of oe-form, with o always somewhat smaller, sometimes with tall e. e is horned, with a short tongue and a squinting eye. Ascenders of tall letters are wedged, leaning towards forking; thorn is noticeably forked. a is quite rounded in form.

An addending hand generally using a somewhat more finely-cut pen. The hand is marked by its tendency to leave a small gap at the top of e and fondness for an upwardly-curling long tongue on e. This hand sometimes adds interlinear Latin glosses or 'vel'-alternatives in other homilies. The same hand can be seen in other places in Hatton 113, generally inserting words either by extending the descender of a letter downward to mark the intended insertion area, or using a double-punctus marking.

The scribe Coleman, who is active in other areas of the manuscript. Coleman leaves marginal comments and interlinear emendations, as well as makes inline corrections by erasing and rewriting material. When attempting to match the display script of the main hand, his imitation is very close (cf. 78v). His personal miniscule is a round Anglo-Saxon miniscule with a slightly squarey character. The horizontal stroke of e is slightly on the diagonal; e is horned and either ligatured to other letters or, when alone, has a small-to-moderate tongue with a pointed end. Round d has a moderately long ascender. Descenders on thorn, wynn, and long s tend to be short, with a curve to the left at the bottom. Ascender of eth is very long and has a downward hairstroke at its tip. Moderate wedging of ascender of thorn and other tall characters, which leans to forking in large format. Coleman's abbreviation strokes are wavy rather than straight. Coleman's marginal rubrics are in rustic capitals. Coleman frequently leaves a scribal sign in the form of an o with a long horizontal crossing stroke. Ker's 'Old English Notes sign "Coleman"', Medium Aevum, xviii (1949) discusses Coleman's marginalia.
